text: Net Neutrality its future is up for
debate and many say its demise could
change your experience online here's how
I have no patience for useless things
when you download from the internet it
arrives in packets of data think of the
packets as literal packages let's say
you want to watch a met flicks movie
which is 10 packages big you order
netflix ships but first it has to go
through a sorting facility in this
analogy that's an internet service
provider like Verizon or Comcast now
what net neutrality means is that all
packages must be delivered at the same
rate if the law changes a company like
Netflix could pay extra to get on the
first truck if a company doesn't pay
they might be shut out of that first
truck they'll get delivered eventually
but if that climactic movie scene
arrives late you know what that means
and it's more than just movies media
columnist David Carr with more who gets
to go fast and who gets to go slow if my
message comes to you really slowly
another person's message comes quickly
and directly who's going to be heard it
as implication for democracy for
commerce in the ongoing debate the
forces of Silicon Valley are on one side
with over 100 companies including Google
and Facebook in support of net
neutrality on the other side are cable
companies with powerful lobbying efforts
in Washington it's time to get the job
finished the figure to watch at the
Federal Communications Commission is
Chairman Tom wheeler he was a big Obama
fundraiser but also is a former lobbyist
for the cable industry mr. wheeler has
vowed to forge ahead with introducing a
new set of rules I believe that this
process will put us on track to
late get to legally enforceable open
Internet rules Silicon Valley stance is
clear the cable company's position is

but that could change net neutrality is
